New Records: Paul van Meekeren finished with 4 for 23, marking a significant performance in the match.
This is the first time Netherlands have won multiple World Cup games.
Key Match Events: Paul van Meekeren took 4 wickets for 23 runs and was named Player of the Match.
Bangladesh's top score was 35 from Miraz, with four of the top six scoring in single digits.
The partnership between Edwards and Engelbrecht significantly hurt Bangladesh.
The Dutch bowlers used extra bounce and turn to their advantage.
Bangladesh's ninth wicket pair hung on, but ultimately fell short.
de Leede's stunning catch dismissed Mahmudullah, a key moment in the match.
Bas de Leede's direct hit run out of Mahedi Hasan was a pivotal moment.
Paul van Meekeren's third wicket in his first spell left Bangladesh reeling at 70/6.
Shakib Al Hasan's dismissal added to Bangladesh's troubles.
Bangladesh's 45 dot balls in the first powerplay were a significant factor.
Netherlands' openers failed again, but Barresi and Ackermann stabilized the innings.
Pre-Game Insights: Netherlands chose to bat first to make an impression in their weaker department.
Bangladesh made changes with Taskin Ahmed returning after a niggle and Mahedi Hasan replacing Nasum Ahmed.
The pitch was expected to be good for batting with cloudy conditions.
Post-Match Reflections: Paul van Meekeren expressed confidence and pride in the team's performance, especially after bouncing back from a heavy defeat against Australia.
The Dutch team celebrated their second win in six games, a significant achievement for them.
There is a slim chance for both Bangladesh and Netherlands to make the semi-finals, but it is highly unlikely.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The match was held at Eden Gardens, Kolkata.
Bangladesh fans were present in large numbers, given the proximity to Kolkata.
The Dutch team had better chances of advancing compared to Bangladesh, but still slim.
